0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• oral inhalation aerosol (Azmacort(R)) was removed from the market effective December 31, 2009 due to the international environmental protection agreement, which calls for the elimination from the market of certain chlorofluorocarbon (CFC)-containing medical products
  • Acquired hemolytic anemia: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief
  • Allergic rhinitis, Perennial or seasonal: NASAL INHALATION, initial and MAX dose, 2 metered sprays (55 mcg/spray) in each nostril once a day (220 mcg/day)
  • Allergic rhinitis, Perennial or seasonal: NASAL INHALATION, maintenance, 1 metered spray (55 mcg/spray) in each nostril once a day (110 mcg/day)
  • Allergic rhinitis, Perennial or seasonal: IM, 40 to 100 mg as single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle
  • Asthma: metered-dose inhaler, 2 ORAL INHALATIONS three to four times daily OR 4 ORAL INHALATIONS twice daily; MAX, 16 inhalations (1200 mcg) per day in divided doses
  • Asthma: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief
  • Collagen disease: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief
  • Disorder of endocrine system: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief
  • Disorder of eye: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief
  • Disorder of eye: INTRAVITREAL, 4 mg/0.05 mL as a single dose
  • Disorder of gastrointestinal tract: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief
  • Disorder of respiratory system: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief
  • Disorder of skin: TOPICAL, apply cream, ointment, lotion, or aerosol to affected areas 2 to 4 times a day
  • Disorder of skin: INTRALESIONAL, initial and maintenance, dose is dependent upon injection site and lesion size, once weekly or less frequently as needed
  • Disorder of skin: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, doses can be adjusted between 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief (Kenalog(R)-40)
  • Ganglion and synovial cyst: INTRA-ARTICULAR, INTRABURSAL, or TENDON-SHEATH INJECTIONS, initial, 2.5 to 15 mg as a single local injection, additional doses can be adjusted to a total of 20 mg or more and administered as needed
  • Ganglion and synovial cyst: INTRALESIONAL, initial and maintenance, dose is dependent upon injection site and lesion size, once weekly or less frequently as needed
  • Inflammatory disorder of musculoskeletal system; Adjunct: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief (Kenalog(R)-40)
  • Inflammatory disorder of musculoskeletal system; Adjunct: INTRA-ARTICULAR, INTRABURSAL, or TENDON-SHEATH INJECTIONS, initial, 2.5 to 15 mg as a single local injection, additional doses can be adjusted between 20 to 40 mg and administered as needed
  • Leukemia: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief
  • Malignant lymphoma: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief
  • Multiple sclerosis: IM, 160 mg injected deeply into gluteal muscle once daily for 7 days, then 64 mg injected deeply into gluteal muscle every other day for one month
  • Nephrotic syndrome, Idiopathic or lupus erythematosus-induced: IM, initial, 60 mg as a single dose injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, additional doses can be adjusted from 2.5 to 100 mg as needed, frequency dependent upon patient response and duration of relief
  • Stomatitis: TOPICAL, apply triamcinolone dental paste to oral mucous membranes 2 to 3 times/day after meals and at bedtime; apply enough to form a thin film over the lesion; do not rub in

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• oral inhalation aerosol (Azmacort(R)) was removed from the market effective December 31, 2009 due to the international environmental protection agreement, which calls for the elimination from the market of certain chlorofluorocarbon (CFC)-containing medical products
  • safety and effectiveness of the nasal inhaler has not been established for children under 2 years of age.
  • safety and effectiveness of the oral dental paste has not been established in children
  • Acquired hemolytic anemia: IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses, injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Allergic rhinitis, Perennial or seasonal: NASAL INHALATION, (12 years and older) initial and MAX dose, 2 metered sprays (55 mcg/spray) in each nostril once a day (220 mcg/day)
  • Allergic rhinitis, Perennial or seasonal: NASAL INHALATION, (12 years and older), maintenance, 1 metered spray (55 mcg/spray) in each nostril once a day (110 mcg/day)
  • Allergic rhinitis, Perennial or seasonal: NASAL INHALATION, (6 to 12 years) initial and maintenance dose, 1 metered spray (55 mcg/spray) in each nostril once a day (110 mcg/day); MAX dose 220 mcg/day
  • Allergic rhinitis, Perennial or seasonal: NASAL INHALATION, (2 to 5 years) initial and maintenance dose, 1 metered spray (55 mcg/spray) in each nostril once a day (110 mcg/day); MAX dose 110 mcg/day
  • Allergic rhinitis, Perennial or seasonal: IM, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Asthma: 6 to 12 years, metered-dose inhaler, 1 to 2 ORAL INHALATIONS three to four times daily OR 2 to 4 ORAL INHALATIONS twice daily; MAX, 12 inhalations (900 mcg) per day in divided doses.
  • Asthma: IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses, injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Collagen disease: IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses, injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Disorder of endocrine system: IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses, injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Disorder of eye: IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Disorder of eye: INTRAVITREAL, 4 mg/0.05 mL as a single dose
  • Disorder of gastrointestinal tract: IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Disorder of respiratory system: IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Disorder of skin: TOPICAL, apply cream, ointment, lotion or aerosol to affected areas 2 to 4 times a day
  • Disorder of skin: INTRALESIONAL, initial and maintenance, dose is dependent upon injection site and lesion size, once weekly or less frequently as needed (Kenalog(R)-10)
  • Disorder of skin: IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Ganglion and synovial cyst: INTRA-ARTICULAR, INTRABURSAL, or TENDON-SHEATH INJECTIONS, initial, 2.5 to 15 mg as a single local injection, additional doses can be adjusted to a total of 20 mg or more and administered as needed
  • Ganglion and synovial cyst: INTRALESIONAL, initial and maintenance, dose is dependent upon injection site and lesion size, once weekly or less frequently as needed
  • Inflammatory disorder of musculoskeletal system; Adjunct: IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses, injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms (Kenalog(R)-40)
  • Inflammatory disorder of musculoskeletal system; Adjunct: INTRA-ARTICULAR, INTRABURSAL, or TENDON-SHEATH INJECTIONS, initial, 2.5 to 15 mg as a single local injection, additional doses can be adjusted between 20 to 40 mg and administered as needed
  • Leukemia: 1 month and older, IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Malignant lymphoma: 1 months and older, IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms
  • Nephrotic syndrome, Idiopathic or lupus erythematosus-induced: older than 2 years, IM, initial, 0.11 to 1.6 mg/kg/day in 3 or 4 divided doses injected deeply into the gluteal muscle, dose may vary upon severity of symptoms

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Acquired hemolytic anemia
  • Allergic rhinitis, Perennial or seasonal
  • Asthma
  • Collagen disease
  • Disorder of endocrine system
  • Disorder of eye
  • Disorder of gastrointestinal tract
  • Disorder of respiratory system
  • Disorder of skin
  • Ganglion and synovial cyst
  • Inflammatory disorder of musculoskeletal system; Adjunct
  • Leukemia
  • Malignant lymphoma
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome, Idiopathic or lupus erythematosus-induced
  • Stomatitis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Macular retinal edema
  • Pain
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy; Adjunct
  • Tight foreskin

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• concomitant administration of live or live, attenuated vaccines
  • hypersensitivity to triamcinolone acetonide or any other component of the product
  • IM injection for idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura
  • primary treatment for status asthmaticus or acute asthma,

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Cardiovascular:
  • -- use with caution in patients with recent myocardial infarction due to risk of left ventricular free-wall rupture
  • -- blood pressure elevations may occur with average to large doses of corticosteroids; monitoring recommended
  • -- fluid retention or edema may occur with average to large doses of corticosteroids; use cautiously in patients with congestive heart failure, hypertension, or renal insufficiency
  • Dermatologic Effects:
  • -- Kaposi sarcoma has been reported with corticosteroid use, especially with long-term therapy; clinical improvement may occur with discontinuation
  • -- injection-site atrophy may occur; avoid injection into deltoid
  • -- conditions which augment systemic absorption of topical corticosteroids (eg, use over large surface areas, prolonged use, and addition of occlusive dressings)
  • -- discontinue topical administration if dermatological infections do not respond to antifungals or antibacterials
  • Endocrine Metabolic Effects:
  • -- fatal adrenal insufficiency has been reported in patients with asthma transferred from systemic to aerosolized corticosteroid therapy
  • -- adrenal insufficiency may occur with transfer from systemic to aerosolized corticosteroid therapy, with increased risk following surgery, trauma, infection, or other stress; monitoring recommended
  • -- hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism may increase or decrease metabolic clearance of corticosteroids, respectively; dose adjustment may be required
  • -- increased risk of metabolic acidosis in premature or low-birthweight neonates (off-label use) due to benzyl alcohol exposure; monitor daily benzyl alcohol metabolic load from all sources with high doses or concomitant medications
  • -- reversible hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis suppression may occur after treatment withdrawal, with potential progression to glucocorticosteroid insufficiency, especially in susceptible patients or with doses higher than recommended
  • -- increased potassium excretion or sodium retention may occur with average to large doses of corticosteroids; use cautiously in patients with congestive heart failure, hypertension, or renal insufficiency
  • Gastrointestinal Effects:
  • -- patients with diverticulitis, active or latent peptic ulcer, fresh intestinal anastomoses, or nonspecific ulcerative colitis may be at increased risk of gastrointestinal perforation; monitoring recommended
  • Hematologic:
  • -- increased risk of hypotension in premature or low-birthweight neonates (off-label use) due to benzyl alcohol exposure; monitor daily benzyl alcohol metabolic load from all sources with high doses or concomitant medications
  • Hepatic Effects:
  • -- patients with cirrhosis may have increased risk of toxicity
  • Immunologic Effects:
  • -- anaphylactoid reactions, including fatalities, have rarely been reported with corticosteroid therapy
  • -- activation of latent disease or worsening active infection may occur (ie, viral, bacterial, fungal, protozoan, or helminthic); amebiasis screening recommended before therapy initiation in at-risk patients
  • -- tuberculosis reactivation may occur; monitoring recommended
  • -- exposure to chicken pox or measles during corticosteroid treatment may result in a more serious or fatal disease course, particularly in patients with no history of these infections
  • -- use cautiously in patients with Strongyloides (threadworm) infestation, as life-threatening enterocolitis and septicemia may develop
  • -- avoid use in patients with systemic fungal infection
  • -- impaired wound healing may occur with use with recent nasal ulcer, surgery, or trauma
  • -- localized Candida albicans infections of the nose, mouth and pharynx have been reported; dose interruption may be required
  • Musculoskeletal Effects:
  • -- risk of bone growth inhibition in pediatric patients; monitoring recommended
  • -- osteoporosis may occur, especially in postmenopausal women; monitoring recommended
  • -- intraarticular administration may damage joint tissues or cause septic arthritis; injection into joints that are unstable or with history of infection not recommended
  • Neurologic:
  • --life-threatening and fatal neurologic events (eg, stroke, cortical blindness, quadriplegia, paraplegia, spinal cord infarction) have occurred with epidural or intrathecal corticosteroid administration (off-label use), with or without fluoroscopy
  • -- avoid use with cerebral malaria
  • -- increased risk of kernicterus in premature or low-birthweight neonates (off-label use) due to benzyl alcohol exposure; monitor daily benzyl alcohol metabolic load from all sources with high doses or concomitant medications
  • -- avoid use or high doses in patients with traumatic brain injury
  • -- increased risk of acute myopathy in patients with neuromuscular transmission disorders (eg, myasthenia gravis) or concurrent use of neuromuscular blockers (eg, pancuronium)
  • Ophthalmic Effects:
  • -- increased risk of secondary ocular infection, cataracts, and glaucoma with corticosteroid use; monitoring recommended
  • -- oral use for optic neuritis not recommended
  • -- avoid use with active ocular herpes simplex
  • -- intraocular administration not recommended, as inflammation (eg, endophthalmitis), increased intraocular pressure, and vision loss have occurred;
  • -- intraocular pressure elevations may occur with long-term use (ie, longer than 6 weeks); monitoring recommended
  • -- benzyl alcohol toxicity may occur with intraocular administration
  • Psychiatric Effects:
  • -- use may aggravate preexisting emotional instability or psychotic tendencies; monitoring recommended
  • Respiratory Effects:
  • -- intranasal administration (ie, nasal turbinates) not recommended
  • Other:
  • --increased risk of fatal "gasping syndrome" in premature or low-birthweight neonates (off-label use) due to benzyl alcohol exposure; monitor daily benzyl alcohol metabolic load from all sources with high doses or concomitant medications
  • -- pediatric patients increased risk of systemic toxicity with topical administration
  • -- not for IV administration
  • -- unmasking of latent conditions (eg, eczema, rhinitis, conjunctivitis) may occur with transfer from systemic to aerosolized corticosteroid therapy, with increased risk following surgery, trauma, infection, or other stress; monitoring recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Triamcinolone: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Endocrine metabolic:Cushing's syndrome
  • Neurologic:Headache (5.5% to 21%)
  • Respiratory:Pharyngitis (5.1% to 25%)
  • Other:Influenza-like illness (2% to 8.9%)
Serious
  • Endocrine metabolic:Secondary hypocortisolism
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (rare)
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident, Infarction of spinal cord, Nerve injury, Paraplegia, Raised intracranial pressure, Seizure, Tetraplegia
  • Ophthalmic:Cataract (rare), Cortical blindness, Glaucoma (rare)
  • Respiratory:Perforation of nasal septum

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Triamcinolone acetonide is a synthetic corticosteroid with anti-inflammatory, antipruritic and antiallergic properties. It also exerts a profound and varied metabolic effects, and changes the body's immune responses to different stimuli. The precise mechanism of action for its antiallergic activity is still unknown.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Intranasal: time to peak concentration, 1.5 h
  • Oral: time to peak concentration, 1.5 h to 2 h

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Intra-articular
    • shake vial well before withdrawing medication; do not use if clumping occurs
    • inject immediately following withdrawal into syringe
  • Intralesional
    • shake vial well before withdrawing medication; do not use if clumping occurs
    • inject immediately following withdrawal into syringe
  • Intramuscular
    • shake vial well before withdrawing medication; do not use if clumping occurs
    • inject immediately following withdrawal into syringe
    • inject deeply into gluteal muscle; use alternate sites for subsequent injections
    • use a minimum needle length of 1.5 inches; a longer needle may be necessary in obese patients
  • Intravitreal
    • refrigerate, do not freeze, protect from light
    • visually inspect prefilled syringe; do not is use if discoloration or particulate matter is identified
    • adequate anesthesia and a broad-spectrum antibiotic should be given prior to injection; the injection procedure should be done under controlled aseptic conditions
    • use 1 syringe per eye; change sterile field, gloves, drapes, eyelid speculum, filter, and injection needles before administration to the other eye
  • Nasal
    • shake pump well before using
    • prime pump prior to first use by actuating 5 times or until a fine mist appears; reprime with 1 spray if pump has not been used for more than 14 days
    • discard after the labeled-number of actuations have been reached (after 120 actuations) even if the bottle is not completely empty
  • Oral
    • (dental paste) press a small amount onto the lesion until a thin film develops; do not rub in
    • (dental paste) bedtime application is optimal; apply after meals if used during the day
  • Topical
    • apply thin film to affected area and rub in gently
    • do not use occlusive dressings unless otherwise directed by physician
    • (aerosol spray) contents are flammable

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• clinical improvement
  • asthma: pulmonary function tests
  • asthma: proper technique with inhaled agents
  • blood pressure, blood glucose, ophthalmic exam (with prolonged therapy)
  • signs and symptoms of infection
  • linear growth velocity in pediatric patients; during prolonged therapy
  • hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis suppression tests; periodically during prolonged therapy

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    • Injection Suspension: 10 MG/ML, 40 MG/ML
    • Mucous Membrane Paste: 0.1 %
    • Nasal Spray: 55 MCG/Actuation
    • Topical Cream: 0.025 %, 0.1 %, 0.5 %
    • Topical Lotion: 0.025 %, 0.1 %
    • Topical Ointment: 0.025 %, 0.1 %, 0.5 %
    • Topical Spray: 0.147 MG/GM
  • Azmacort
    Inhalation Aerosol Powder: 100 MCG/Actuation
  • Kenalog-10
    Injection Suspension: 10 MG/ML
  • Kenalog-40
    Injection Suspension: 40 MG/ML
  • Kenalog In Orabase
    Mucous Membrane Paste: 0.1 %
  • Kenalog
    Topical Spray: 0.147 MG/GM
  • Nasacort Allergy 24HR
    Nasal Spray: 55 MCG/Actuation
  • Nasacort AQ
    Nasal Spray: 55 MCG/Actuation
  • Oralone
    Mucous Membrane Paste: 0.1 %
  • Triamcot
    Topical Cream: 0.1 %
  • Trianex
    Topical Ointment: 0.05 %
  • Triderm
    Topical Cream: 0.1 %
  • Triesence
    Injection Suspension: 40 MG/ML

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
CORTICOSTEROIDS
USES: Antiinflammatory agents used to treat a variety of clinical conditions, including adrenal insufficiency, asthma, various allergy disorders, and autoimmune disorders (eg, hemolytic anemia, rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus). Corticosteroids are available in oral, parenteral, inhalational, and topical formulations. PHARMACOLOGY: Multiple mechanisms of action including anti-inflammatory activity, immunosuppressive properties, and antiproliferative actions. Anti-inflammatory effects result from decreased formation, release and activity of the mediators of inflammation (eg, kinins, histamine, liposomal enzymes, prostaglandins, leukotrienes) which reduced the initial manifestations of the inflammatory process. The immunosuppressive properties decrease the response to delayed and immediate hypersensitivity reactions (eg, type III and type IV). The antiproliferative effects reduce hyperplastic tissue characteristic of psoriasis. TOXICOLOGY: Corticosteroids decrease calcium absorption, increase calcium excretion, and inhibit osteoblast formation, leading to a decrease in bone formation and an increase in bone resorption, thereby contributing to the development of osteoporosis. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Acute toxicity following overdose is rare. OVERDOSE: Acute ingestion is rarely a clinical problem. Acute adrenal insufficiency rarely reported after overdose. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Cardiac dysrhythmias (ie, atrial fibrillation)(methylPREDNISolone), seizures (methylPREDNISolone), anaphylaxis. CHRONIC EXPOSURE: Cushingoid appearance, muscle wasting and weakness, hypertension, hyperglycemia, subcapsulary cataracts and glaucoma, osteoporosis, psychosis. ABRUPT WITHDRAWAL: Dysphoria, irritability, emotional liability, depression, fatigue, anxiety, depersonalization, myalgia, and arthralgia.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
CORTICOSTEROIDS
  • Support: MANAGEMENT OF TOXICITY: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive. Seizures have been reported with IV pulse methylPREDNISolone therapy. If seizures occur, administer IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates.
  • Decontamination: PREHOSPITAL: Serious toxicity is not expected after ingestion of corticosteroids alone, and prehospital gastrointestinal decontamination is not routinely required. HOSPITAL: Significant toxicity is not expected after overdose; gastrointestinal decontamination is generally not necessary. Activated charcoal should be considered after extremely large ingestions or if more toxic coingestants are involved.
  • Airway management: Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation may be required in patients with severe allergic reactions, but this is rare.
  • Antidote: None
  • Acute allergic reaction: MILD/MODERATE: Monitor airway. Administer antihistamines with or without inhaled beta agonists, corticosteroids or epinephrine. SEVERE: Oxygen, aggressive airway management, antihistamines, epinephrine, corticosteroids, ECG monitoring and IV fluids.
  • Monitoring of patient: Routine laboratory studies are not likely to be necessary after acute overdose. Serum electrolytes and glucose are useful to assess for adverse effects from chronic therapy. Monitor vital signs, fluid and electrolyte status as indicated. Monitor neurologic status as indicated in symptomatic patients. Plasma concentrations are not readily available or clinically useful in the management of overdose.
  • Enhanced elimination procedure: Hemodialysis and hemoperfusion are UNLIKELY to be of value because of the high degree of protein binding and large volume of distribution.
  • Patient disposition: HOME CRITERIA: Patients with a minor unintentional exposure who are asymptomatic or have mild symptoms can likely be managed at home. OBSERVATION CRITERIA: Moderate to severely symptomatic patients and those with deliberate overdose should be sent to a healthcare facility for evaluation and treated until symptoms resolve. ADMISSION CRITERIA: Patients who remain symptomatic despite adequate treatment should be admitted. CONSULT CRITERIA: Consult a Poison Center for assistance in managing patients with severe toxicity or in whom the diagnosis is unclear.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
CORTICOSTEROIDS
TOXICITY: Acute ingestion is rarely a clinical problem; effects rarely occur with administration of less than three weeks duration. An adolescent ingested 30 mg dexamethasone and subsequently developed acute adrenal insufficiency. Patient recovered following administration of methylPREDNISolone. CHRONIC EXPOSURE: Six infants (aged 3 to 8 months) who were treated with large amounts (up to 10 tubes for 1.5 to 5 months) of topical corticosteroids for diaper dermatitis developed Cushing's syndrome and adrenocortical insufficiency. Hepatomegaly and hepatosteatosis were observed in 5 and 3 patients, respectively. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies with drug and indication.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to seek immediate medical attention for symptoms of anaphylaxis. Severe anaphylactic/anaphylactoid reactions, some fatal, have been reported.
  • Advise patient to avoid vaccines during therapy unless approved by healthcare professional.
  • Patient should immediately report exposure to chickenpox or measles.
  • Tell patient using inhaled form that this drug is not indicated for acute asthma attacks.
  • This drug may cause impaired skin healing, decreased body growth, hypercortisolism (weight gain, fatigue, muscle weakness, facial rounding, fragile/thin skin), osteoporosis, depression, euphoria, hyperglycemia, or cataract.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of infection or primary adrenocortical insufficiency (fatigue, muscle weakness, loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, low blood pressure).
  • Advise patients to take the drug exactly as prescribed. Patient should not discontinue the drug, unless directed by the prescribing physician.
  • Patients using nasal form should not blow nose for 15 min after administration. Also advise patient to report occurrence of nose injury to healthcare professional.
  • Instruct patients using inhaled form to rinse mouth with water after each use to prevent oral infections.
  • Patient should not use an occlusive dressing over areas treated with the topical formulation.
  • Advise patient on proper administration technique, depending on form.
